block.p: Re ''Bush Delays an Execution for the 1st Time in 5 Years'' (news article, June 2): Gov. George W. Bush granted a condemned man a reprieve. The man, Ricky McGinn, will now have a chance to prove his innocence.

Re ''Bush Delays an Execution for the 1st Time in 5 Years'' (news article, June 2): Gov. George W. Bush granted a condemned man a reprieve. The man, Ricky McGinn, will now have a chance to prove his innocence.

While we are applauding this search for the truth, we should not lose sight of the shocking and depressing fact that the judicial system provided this resident of death row no such opportunity. This is because the present jurisprudence in capital cases increasingly forecloses review of meritorious claims that the defendant should not be subject to the ultimate punishment.
Consideration of these claims should be the everyday obligation of our courts, not something that is left to the slim chance that a particular claim will catch a presidential candidate's eye.
The writer is chairman of the American Bar Association's Death Penalty Representation Project.
